hypotheses.title: DNS Tunneling via nslookup in ClickFix Social Engineering Attacks
hypotheses.description: Threat actors from the ClickFix group are increasingly using DNS tunneling via the nslookup command to deliver second-stage payloads (e.g., ModeloRAT). Attackers trick users into copying and pasting malicious nslookup commands into Windows Run or PowerShell, which resolve custom DNS queries to fetch encoded payloads. This technique bypasses traditional network security controls that focus on HTTP/HTTPS traffic.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1048.003 - Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process creation logs with command-line arguments, especially 'nslookup' usage, and parent-child process relationships
tools: EDR (e.g., CrowdStrike, SentinelOne), Windows Event Logs (Event ID 4688), Sysmon

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS query logs with unusually long subdomains, high-frequency DNS queries to uncommon TLDs, and DNS responses with large TXT records
tools: DNS logging (e.g., Cisco Umbrella, Infoblox), SIEM with DNS analytics

hunting_tactics.description: Search for suspicious nslookup usage that includes non-standard DNS queries used for data exfiltration or staging.
sample_queries: index=windows EventCode=4688 CommandLine=*nslookup* AND (CommandLine=*TXT* OR CommandLine=*A* AND (CommandLine=*\x* OR CommandLine=*base64* OR CommandLine=*%*%* OR CommandLine=*|* OR CommandLine=*%COMSPEC%*))
index=network_dns earliest=-7d | stats count by query_name, query_type, src_ip | where query_type="TXT" AND len(query_name) > 100 AND count > 5
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup commands with encoded data in DNS queries, especially those containing base64-like strings, hex-encoded data, or long subdomains; repeated DNS TXT queries to suspicious domains; nslookup invoked by non-standard processes (e.g., cmd.exe spawned by Office apps or browsers)

hunting_tactics.description: Look for signs of fake CAPTCHA, error, or update prompts that lead users to execute nslookup commands.
sample_queries: index=web_proxy earliest=-14d (url="*forms.google*ss-o*" OR url="*forms.google*ss-o*" OR url="*google*ss-o*") OR (user_agent="*Chrome*" AND (referer="*facebook.com*" OR referer="*linkedin.com*") AND url="*forms.google*ss-o*")
index=endpoint_process parent_process=explorer.exe OR parent_process=chrome.exe OR parent_process=msedge.exe process=cmd.exe CommandLine=*nslookup*
hunting_tactics.look_for: Fake Google Forms subdomains (e.g., forms.google.ss-o[.]com), browser-initiated nslookup execution, and nslookup commands executed shortly after visiting suspicious domains or receiving phishing emails

network_patterns: High-frequency DNS queries to same domain in short time window
DNS queries to domains with base64-like patterns
user_agent_strings: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/145.0.0.0 Safari/537.36
other_indicators: Parent process being Office apps (outlook.exe, winword.exe) or browsers (chrome.exe, msedge.exe)

recommended_actions: Block nslookup execution from non-system processes via AppLocker or EDR policies
Alert on DNS queries with unusually long subdomains (>100 chars) or high TXT query volume
Review recent phishing campaigns targeting employees for nslookup诱饵
Verify patch status for Notepad++ and VS Code extensions to prevent initial compromise

hypotheses.title: OpenClaw AI Agent Configuration Theft via Infostealers
hypotheses.description: Infostealer malware (e.g., LummaStealer, AMOS) has been observed exfiltrating OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot/Moltbot) configuration files and gateway tokens. These files contain API keys, credentials, and agent settings used for AI-assisted workflows. Attackers target developers and IT staff who use OpenClaw, indicating a shift toward stealing 'digital identity' rather than just browser credentials.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials in Files

data_sources_needed.specific_data: File system access logs for OpenClaw-related paths, process execution of known infostealers (e.g., LummaStealer.exe), and memory dumps for credential harvesting
tools: EDR (e.g., CrowdStrike, SentinelOne), Sysmon Event ID 11 (FileCreate), Event ID 1 (ProcessCreation)

data_sources_needed.specific_data: API key usage anomalies, token refresh patterns, and unusual access to AI service endpoints (e.g., OpenAI, Anthropic, Google Gemini)
tools: Cloud SIEM (e.g., Wiz, Datadog), Okta, Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps

hunting_tactics.description: Search for processes accessing OpenClaw configuration directories or files, especially when combined with network exfiltration.
sample_queries: index=endpoint (file_path=*openclaw* OR file_path=*clawdbot* OR file_path=*moltbot* OR file_path=*ClawHub*) AND (process_name=*python* OR process_name=*node* OR process_name=*java*) AND (event_type=FileCreate OR event_type=FileDelete OR event_type=FileRead)
index=cloud_logs service=api_gateway (user_agent=*OpenClaw* OR user_agent=*ClawHub*) AND (status_code=200 AND response_size > 10000) AND (endpoint=/api/v1/token OR endpoint=/api/v1/config)
hunting_tactics.look_for: Access to %APPDATA%\OpenClaw, ~/.config/clawdbot, or /var/lib/openclaw directories; processes like LummaStealer.exe, AMOS.exe, or CastleLoader.exe reading config files; unusual outbound connections to non-standard ports from OpenClaw processes

hunting_tactics.description: Look for anomalous usage of AI APIs or tokens, such as unexpected volume, time-of-day, or geographic location.
sample_queries: index=cloud_logs (service=gemini OR service=claude OR service=openai) (event_type=token_created OR event_type=api_key_used) AND (user_agent=*OpenClaw* OR user_agent=*ClawHub* OR user_agent=*Moltbot*) AND (status=success) AND (ip_location!=user_location)
index=identity (event_type=login OR event_type=token_refresh) AND (service IN ('OpenAI', 'Anthropic', 'Google AI')) AND (user_agent=*OpenClaw* OR user_agent=*ClawHub*) AND (risk_score > 0.7)
hunting_tactics.look_for: API tokens used from new IPs or countries, high-frequency API calls from a single agent, and token usage from processes associated with OpenClaw or infostealers

network_patterns: Outbound HTTPS to non-standard AI service endpoints
DNS queries to clawhub.ai or similar domains
Large outbound payloads (>10KB) from OpenClaw processes
other_indicators: API keys exposed in environment variables or config files
OpenClaw processes spawned by non-interactive sessions

recommended_actions: Audit all OpenClaw/ClawHub deployments and rotate all API keys and tokens
Implement strict egress filtering for AI service endpoints
Enable MFA for all AI platform accounts and monitor for anomalous usage
Deploy EDR rules to detect file access to OpenClaw config directories

hypotheses.title: AI Assistant Abuse as C2 Proxy via Web Browsing Features
hypotheses.description: AI assistants like Microsoft Copilot and xAI Grok with web browsing capabilities are being abused as stealthy C2 relays. Attackers craft prompts that instruct the AI to fetch payloads or exfiltrate data via legitimate web requests, blending into normal enterprise traffic and evading traditional network security controls.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTPS traffic to AI service endpoints (e.g., copilot.microsoft.com, grok.com) with unusual payload patterns or prompt structures
tools: TLS inspection, Proxy logs (e.g., Zscaler, Bluecoat), SIEM with DLP integration

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs for AI assistant applications (e.g., Copilot.exe, Grok.exe) and network calls made by these processes
tools: EDR, Sysmon, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Detect AI-assisted C2 via prompt analysis
hunting_tactics.description: Search for AI assistant prompts that include instructions to fetch URLs, download files, or send data to external endpoints.
sample_queries: index=endpoint (process_name=*copilot* OR process_name=*grok* OR process_name=*gemini*) AND (CommandLine=*fetch* OR CommandLine=*download* OR CommandLine=*send* OR CommandLine=*exfiltrat*) AND (CommandLine=*http* OR CommandLine=*https*)

index=proxy earliest=-7d (user_agent=*Copilot* OR user_agent=*Grok*) AND (url=*api.openai.com* OR url=*generativelanguage.googleapis.com*) AND (request_body=*fetch* OR request_body=*URL* OR request_body=*download*)
hunting_tactics.look_for: AI assistant processes making HTTP/HTTPS requests to non-standard endpoints, prompts containing 'fetch URL', 'download file', or 'send data to' instructions, and AI assistant processes spawned by suspicious parent processes (e.g., cmd.exe, powershell.exe)

hunting_tactics.description: Look for AI assistants being used to gather intelligence about internal systems or users via web searches or API queries.
sample_queries: index=cloud_logs (service=gemini OR service=claude OR service=copilot) (prompt=*internal network* OR prompt=*company email* OR prompt=*server IP* OR prompt=*employee name*) AND (status=success)
index=endpoint (process_name=*copilot* OR process_name=*grok*) AND (CommandLine=*search* OR CommandLine=*query*) AND (CommandLine=*internal* OR CommandLine=*admin* OR CommandLine=*password*)
hunting_tactics.look_for: AI prompts referencing internal infrastructure, employee names, or credentials; AI assistants making requests to internal DNS names or IP ranges; unusual AI assistant usage during off-hours

network_patterns: HTTPS to AI service domains with large request/response bodies
AI assistant processes making DNS queries to internal domains
Unusual timing of AI assistant network activity (e.g., after hours)
user_agent_strings: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Copilot/1.0 Safari/537.36
other_indicators: AI assistant prompts containing base64-encoded data
AI assistant responses with embedded URLs or commands
AI assistant processes spawned by non-interactive sessions

recommended_actions: Disable web browsing features in AI assistants for high-risk users or environments
Implement DLP policies to block AI assistants from accessing sensitive data
Monitor AI assistant network traffic for anomalies and unusual prompts
Review and restrict AI assistant permissions in Microsoft 365 and Google Workspace

hypotheses.title: Firmware-Level Android Backdoor (Keenadu) Infection via OTA Updates
hypotheses.description: The Keenadu Android backdoor is embedded in device firmware during the manufacturing phase and spreads via signed OTA updates. It infects the Zygote process to compromise all apps on the device, enabling ad fraud and full remote control. This poses a significant supply chain risk, especially for devices used in enterprise BYOD or corporate-issued scenarios.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1553.001 - Code Signing: Subvert Trust Controls

data_sources_needed.specific_data: OTA update logs, device firmware version, and app installation history
tools: MDM platforms (e.g., Intune, Jamf), Android Enterprise logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs for Zygote-related activity, suspicious app behavior (e.g., excessive network usage, battery drain)
tools: Mobile EDR (e.g., SentinelOne Mobile, Zimperium), Android Auditd

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Detect Keenadu infection via Zygote hooking
hunting_tactics.description: Search for evidence of Zygote process modification or injection, which is a hallmark of Keenadu and Triada.
sample_queries: index=android_logs (process_name=*zygote* OR process_name=*zygote64*) AND (event_type=library_loaded OR event_type=process_spawn) AND (library_path=*libVndxUtils* OR library_path=*libandroid_runtime.so*)
index=mdm earliest=-30d AND (firmware_version IN ('2025.12.*', '2026.01.*')) AND (ota_update_status='success') AND (device_model IN ('Alldocube', 'Generic Android Tablet'))
hunting_tactics.look_for: Zygote loading unexpected shared libraries (e.g., libVndxUtils.a), firmware versions associated with Keenadu infections, and devices from compromised OEMs (e.g., Alldocube)

hunting_tactics.description: Look for suspicious app behavior indicative of ad fraud, such as background network activity or fake clicks.
sample_queries: index=android_logs (package_name=*com.google.android.gms* OR package_name=*com.android.vending*) AND (event_type=network_activity) AND (bytes_sent > 100000 AND bytes_received > 50000) AND (foreground=false)
index=mdm (device_status='compromised') AND (battery_drain_rate > 20%/hr) AND (network_usage > 500MB/day)
hunting_tactics.look_for: Apps making network requests while in background, high data usage from non-user-facing apps, and devices with unusual battery drain or network patterns

network_patterns: Background network activity to ad fraud C2 domains
DNS queries to known ad fraud domains (e.g., adfonic.net, m6d.com)
other_indicators: Firmware versions from compromised OEMs (e.g., Alldocube, generic tablets)
Zygote injection detected via memory scanning

recommended_actions: Enforce MDM policies to block OTA updates from untrusted sources
Deploy mobile EDR with firmware scanning capabilities
Audit device procurement processes to avoid compromised OEMs
Isolate and wipe devices showing signs of Zygote injection

hypotheses.title: BeyondTrust Privileged Access Management (PAM) Exploitation via CVE-2026-1731
hypotheses.description: Attackers have actively exploited the unauthenticated RCE vulnerability CVE-2026-1731 in BeyondTrust Remote Support and Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products within hours of PoC release. Successful exploitation allows full remote code execution without authentication, enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation to access high-value systems.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1021.001 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
T1548.002 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism: Bypass User Account Control

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTP/HTTPS traffic to BeyondTrust RS/PRA endpoints (e.g., /rs/remote, /pra/api) with unusual request patterns
Process execution logs for BeyondTrust services (e.g., BTRemoteSupport.exe, BTPRAService.exe) and unusual child processes

hunting_tactics.description: Search for requests to BeyondTrust endpoints with crafted payloads that trigger the unauthenticated RCE.
sample_queries: index=network earliest=-7d (url=*beyondtrust* OR url=*rs/remote* OR url=*pra/api*) AND (method=POST OR method=GET) AND (user_agent=*curl* OR user_agent=*wget* OR user_agent=*python-requests*) AND (request_body=*exploit* OR request_body=*shell* OR request_body=*cmd.exe*)

index=endpoint (process_name=*BTRemoteSupport* OR process_name=*BTPRAService*) AND (parent_process=*http.sys* OR parent_process=*w3wp.exe*) AND (CommandLine=*whoami* OR CommandLine=*ipconfig* OR CommandLine=*net user*)
hunting_tactics.look_for: Unauthenticated POST requests to BeyondTrust endpoints, requests with unusual headers or payloads, and BeyondTrust processes spawning cmd.exe or powershell.exe

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Identify lateral movement via compromised PAM
hunting_tactics.description: Look for suspicious SMB or RDP activity originating from systems with BeyondTrust installed, indicating potential lateral movement.
sample_queries: index=windows (EventCode=5145 OR EventCode=5156) AND (share_name=*\admin$* OR share_name=*\c$*) AND (src_ip IN (SELECT src_ip FROM index=network WHERE url=*beyondtrust*))

index=endpoint (process_name=*mstsc.exe* OR process_name=*psexec.exe*) AND (src_ip IN (SELECT src_ip FROM index=network WHERE url=*beyondtrust*)) AND (dst_ip IN (SELECT dst_ip FROM index=windows WHERE EventCode=4624))
hunting_tactics.look_for: SMB connections to admin shares from BeyondTrust hosts, RDP sessions from compromised PAM servers, and unusual process creation on high-value systems

network_patterns: POST requests with large or unusual payloads
other_indicators: BeyondTrust servers with unpatched versions (pre-2024 SU5)
Unusual outbound connections from BeyondTrust servers
SMB/RDP activity from BeyondTrust hosts to high-value targets

recommended_actions: Immediately patch BeyondTrust RS/PRA to latest version
Block unauthenticated access to BeyondTrust endpoints via firewall/WAF
Audit all BeyondTrust deployments for signs of compromise
Review and restrict SMB/RDP access from PAM servers

unique_mitre_techniques: T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials in Files
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1553.001 - Code Signing: Subvert Trust Controls
T1021.001 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
T1548.002 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism: Bypass User Account Control
T1048.003 - Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
